chapter.title: Updated Advanced Analytics Platform Proof of Concept Use Case(s) (Months 13-24)

section.title: Background
section.para: In today’s current state, Laboratory Real-World Data (RWD) is of remarkably low-quality which affects quality of care.Currently, standard test results and test information are encoded both inconsistently and incompletely. The current laboratory data standards alone (e.g., Logical Observation Identifiers, Names, and Codes (LOINC®)) do not provide the level of detail or precision needed for the advanced analytics that power the clinical, regulatory, public health, and coverage determination decisions.

As a result of these low-quality data, patient safety is at risk, quality of care diminishes, and accuracy of test results come into question. Simultaneously, this low-quality data has negatively impacted operational efficiency within both federal and private sectors. Examples of negative effects of federal agencies are seen below:

listitem.para: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC)

Epidemiologists studying disease mutation and forecasting strain/variant proliferation (e.g., flu, Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19)) do not have access to granular test details (test targets, test methods, specimen source and specimen collection location —i.e., a pharyngeal location or a nasal location) that could help identify new variants and assess real-time test performance.
Reviewers and post-market surveyors do not have high-quality and consistently represented RWD to help them evaluate and monitor the safety and effectiveness of laboratory devices.
Practicing clinicians have limited ability to interpret individual tests for false negative and false positive results because the details of the test are unavailable.

section.title: Proposed Solution
section.para: In order to address these gaps in data, the Systemic Harmonization and Interoperability Enhancement for Laboratory Data (SHIELD) Collaborative Community (CC) curated a device extension that creates interoperability between different systems. The extension was designed to be an authoritative source to educate end-users on populating their data dictionaries. The device extension will provide guidance and interact across systems on which data standards codes (e.g. LOINC®/Systematized Nomenclature of Medicine Clinical Term (SNOMED CT®)) are to be used for specific tests and/or devices. This source, designed by the CC, will link the laboratory analyzer with the necessary information to support the comparison of test results without switching laboratory codes, thus, increasing data quality.

The device extension is intended to serve as a database that improves the quality and interoperability of laboratory data. The extension does this by utilizing Unique Device Identifiers (UDI) to link individual In-Vitro Diagnostic (IVD) devices to a database that contains the test’s metadata, including units of measurement and data standard codes. It will provide insightful guidance on which data standard (e.g. LOINC®/SNOMED CT®) codes should be used on specific tests and devices. It will also enable linking laboratory analyzers with information to support the comparison of test results using the same laboratory codes.

Our device extension was designed to address gaps in the current system. The extension is intended to be a reliable reference source to inform end users how to populate data dictionaries. This reduces the variance in laboratory data representation and will also provide laboratories with guidance on LOINC/SNOMED CT code usage for specific tests. This extension also enables the linking of laboratory devices through Unique Device Identifier (UDIs) with supporting contextual information to enable deeper insights and accurate comparison of results.

These two benefits directly contribute to a dramatic enhancement of advanced analytical capabilities across a variety of mediums. Additional detail and consistent encoding of test results empower artificial intelligence (AI) algorithms to uncover deeper health insights that aid in treatment.

section.title: Development and Implementation Progress
section.para: Data interoperability begins with the ability to represent data in a uniformed way with quality standards that are adhered to by the community. SNOMED CT® and LOINC® are two international interoperability standards that both work to communicate clinical data information, LOINC® focusing on clinical and laboratory observations and SNOMED CT® focusing on clinical terminology for diagnoses, procedures, findings, and more.

LOINC® and SNOMED CT® signed an agreement in October 2022 to collaborate the work between the two standards. The shared effort worked to eliminate duplicative data between the standards and integrate shared information to create an extension of SNOMED CT® with LOINC® knowledge standards included. The collaborative use of these terminologies will provide defined and accessible formats and concepts to represent data captured in laboratories or clinical settings.

The LOINC® Ontology SNOMED CT® Browser builds on the capabilities of the SNOMED CT® Browser by providing visibility to LOINC® data through search or query. The impact the agreement has on the interoperability community spans across the healthcare IT industry by bridging two organizations who are leaders in terminology standards and interoperability.

The collaborative efforts of the LOINC® Ontology SNOMED CT® Browser have produced a suite of increased functionality and tools that enable increased interoperability and integrated knowledge, including:

listitem.para: Search functionality in the LOINC® Ontology SNOMED CT® Browser
Concept viewing and detailed concept insights in the LOINC® Ontology SNOMED CT® Browser
Utilization of the LOINC® Ontology SNOMED CT® Browser for identifying equivalence
Contribution enabled integrations to continuously improve the LOINC® Ontology SNOMED CT® Browser

section.para: The SNOMED LOINC® Collaborative Agreement has made significant strides in technical communications by providing comprehensive documentation on the processes used to link the two data standards. The ontology browser homepage offers an introductory technical explanation, detailing the content inclusions, modeling guidelines, concept/attribute representation, and future steps for improving the browser. This documentation is crucial for both technical and non-technical audiences, offering insights into the collaborative processes and technical efforts, and allowing individuals to understand the development and align their own implementations accordingly. The availability of this information ensures transparency and facilitates a deeper understanding of the integration efforts.

Looking forward, the collaboration faces challenges in integrated knowledge communications and ensuring end-user adoption. The virtual location for the LOINC®-SNOMED CT® Ontology Browser showcases the progress made but lacks clear communication of the overarching goals. Engaging the community and building trust is essential to advancing healthcare information technology, and this can be achieved by enhancing understanding and support. The device extension will utilize the most recent updates published to the LOINC®-SNOMED CT® Ontology Browser. The ability of the device extension to utilize relevant standards from the source enhances effective communication strategies, which are critical for promoting tool adoption, requiring tailored messaging for different end-user segments. The end-user adoption strategy must balance detailed technical guidance for experts with non-technical communications that highlight the benefits and address specific pain points. This dual approach, including user guides, collaboration forums, and feedback channels, will support operational collaboration and encourage broader user engagement with the tools.

section.title: Use Case Purpose
section.para: To better understand the impact and value of the device extension, a use case diagram has been developed to showcase the multiple high-level functions and scope of systems a patient could interact with as a part of a unique care journey. SHIELD has utilized an infectious disease care diagram to highlight the functionality and impact of this tool in the patient care journey while focusing on a plethora of use cases with an emphasis on preventive care. The use case, while iterative, is subjected to evolution based on additional stakeholder feedback. These use cases aim to comprehensively detail how the implementation of integrated knowledge resources, such as the device extension, will enrich data quality and empower advanced analytical tools to drive enhanced patient care.

section.title: Patient Journey Use Case (Emerging Infectious Disease)
section.para: The Emerging Infectious Disease Use Case, depicted in Figure 1, showcases the details of a patient's journey within medical facilities and processes taking place during an emerging infectious disease, covering an array of processes from symptom recognition to final diagnosis. As seen below, the primary patient journey is denoted by blue. This is where a patient who has been either notified of an exposure (Figure 1, Box 1) or begins to develop symptoms that align with that of an emerging infectious disease (Figure 1, Box 2) is interacting with the various points of care. This journey covers the patient's whole journey within the healthcare ecosystem, culminating in a diagnosis of chronic post-infectious disease (Figure 1, Box 1 – 9).

To fully understand the patient care journey, the individual sub-cycles (black in Figure 2) denote the potential processes where a patient interacts with different care delivery individuals, systems, and/or organizations. These sub-cycles are utilized to collect data, inform decision-making for the patient outcome, and/or further exchange data to improve the healthcare ecosystem's understanding and diagnosis of emerging infectious diseases. This results in specific secondary processes that interconnect between the patient journey and differing state/federal health organizations that are responsible for the reporting and diagnostic device monitoring for public health reporting (Yellow, Figure 1, Box 12, 16, 22).

Our device extension was designed to interconnect these sub cycles, which correspond to health IT platforms or systems, to inform individual patient care outcomes and public health reporting. It can support the increased interconnectivity between healthcare ecosystem entities. These entities, often terminologists, are responsible for creating and extending relevant terminology subsets or modules. Supported by our Integrated Knowledge Management (IKM) environment, this procedure enables authoring a new extension record and integrates the newly formed terminology subsets. Figure 2 showcases how an IKM-powered ecosystem would interact with patients and evolve based on the advances in clinical diagnostics during an infectious disease outbreak.

Like Figure 1, Figure 2 showcases a patient's journey through the healthcare system. For example, if a patient needs to order an Over-The-Counter (OTC) emerging infectious disease test kit, the patient must use a patient portal that has been enabled with the appropriate listing of tests. Figure 2 showcases that certain functions are only actionable if the current Information Technology (IT) Systems, relevant to the career journey, and key players across the organization update the existing health terminology gaps currently enacted and affect patient care. Utilizing the IKM environment, our device extension provides the functionality to efficiently reconcile these gaps in standards that have been discovered as a result of:

section.title: Introduction to Secondary Processes of Emerging Infectious Disease Use Case
section.para: Secondary process documentation has been provided below to enhance understanding of these process flows and showcase the high-level process documentation of our device extension. These process flows dive further into the patient journey and highlight the unique data transfers that occur while detailing the effective use of the device extension in Symptom Surveillance, which overviews the patient data relating to acute symptoms, including questionaries, reporting data, and recording negative symptoms, to highlight risk and protocol. These secondary processes, in addition, highlight the advanced flow of data, expanding how Testing Recommendations occur and how Comparator Testing will take place. The following sections showcase the device extension’s ability to interconnect different large-scale organization databases and the potential for device interoperability.

section.title: Sub-Cycle 1: Symptom Surveillance
section.para: The first secondary process documentation highlights the data processes and flows that occur when individual patient data, along its emerging infectious disease journey, integrates with the larger symptom surveillance ecosystem. As individual data is obtained at the various collection points throughout diagnosis, testing, and treatment processes, this information can be directly aggregated into the larger data repository/lakes that will enable public health entities to research and analyze macro-level data patterns and trends. These data inputs into repositories can be supported by Integrated Knowledge Exchange (IKE) solutions that enables seamless and lossless data transfer/exchange, ensuring that data collection can be interoperable across disparate systems. As this data is collected and assessed, new and/or unusual associated symptoms or risk factors may be identified and reported, leading public health institutions to update warnings and recommendations to clinical protocols to ensure the collection of respective data is captured supporting the identification of these newly identified facets.

As public health institutions update this information, data collection processes, such as questionnaires, need to be updated as well to coincide with these updates. IKE solutions including Komet enable the modifications of concepts directly in a single source that can be integrated across the various data standards and implemented into data collection tools automatically. Once the data collection methods are updated with new concept definitions and specifications based on public health recommendations, future patient care journeys have the functionality to capture the new information effectively and securely to track performance in the future. section.title: Sub-Cycle 2: Comparator Testing
section.para: Sub-Cycle 2 references FIGURE 1 box 16, specifying an additional process that may occur when administering an over-the-counter (OTC test to diagnose emerging infectious disease(s)). In this sub-cycle, the individual patient data entering the cycle are additional samples collected during the OTC test that serve as the samples for Return to Lab (RTL) testing. RTL testing can be utilized for (1) providing a “Gold Standard” test that has a higher rate of accuracy of positivity/negativity to ensure accurate diagnosis and/or (2) post-market surveillance of diagnostic testing performance for regulatory test decisions. An RTL test may be completed with its results returned to a patient’s care journey, with the test result data being integrated with data repositories/lakes and available for public health research. In this research, it may be determined that a diagnostic test should be fully approved from an investigative test to a full market test, or public health institutions may report warnings, recommend alterations to specifications, or even fully remove the test. Regardless of comparator testing outcomes, IKE solutions provide the functionality to modify device-level data specifications to adhere to public health institutions’ updates seamlessly into knowledge resources and systems. section.title: Sub-Cycle 3: Revised Testing Recommendations
section.para: The last secondary process documentation highlights the additional data flow that occurs during a medical consultation during a patient’s journey through the emerging infectious disease use case. When that medical consult occurs, additional patient data is collected and will be integrated into the larger RWD repositories for use amongst the greater research and public health institutions to assess patterns and trends. As that data is analyzed, new associated risk factors and/or comorbidities may be identified to bolster identification and diagnosis of an emerging infectious disease.

Public health institutions, as well as peer-reviewed journals, will submit insights and publications for the healthcare ecosystem to adopt into their practices to capture any risk factors, or comorbidities in the medical consultation process, in the future to identify any additional factors that may impact emerging infectious disease diagnosis. These new identifications can be implemented into the healthcare information technology ecosystem using IKE solutions, such as Komet, to modify concept data to include comorbidities within their definitions to ensure the capture of that new factor to consider with the emerging infectious disease. section.title: Advanced Analytics Capabilities
section.para: The patient journey as described in Figure 2 depicts the patient moving through a variety of healthcare actions and processes. The incorporation of IKE solutions into these spaces provides an opportunity for increased support in the development and maintenance of high-quality data elements. The patient journey can be supplemented with IKE solutions such as Komet to modify, author and exchange novel data concepts in an application and share that information across disparate data platforms/systems. IKE is empowered by collaborative efforts across the healthcare ecosystem to develop, assess, and implement solutions to integrate knowledge resources into a shared environment with seamless capabilities for the variety of needs that healthcare information technology requires.

section.title: Implications and Considerations for Use
section.para: The processes that the patient interacts with on their journey have a direct need for data to be available across systems to coordinate actions and recommendations accurately and effectively to the patient.
Key drivers to consider for the critical need for the implementation of IKE solutions include:

listitem.para: Healthcare data requires reproducible standards: Healthcare data exchange requires that data collection methods are reproducibly encoded using industry coding standards. Without IKE tools, such as Komet, to bring together disparate standards, the reproducibility of data encoding is stunted.

Disparate standards require a centralized repository: The knowledge from standard terminologies that are used to encode data elements need to be managed so that implementers can easily handle dependencies, version control, and data provenance for the integrity of patient records. Komet, via the IKE environment, can enable such data management for informed decision making.

Data gaps require real-time modification: Operational realities, such as those experienced during an emergent infectious disease, necessitate the ability to dynamically adjust clinical terminologies at a local level with the goal of reconciling those adjustments with larger standards bodies once available. IKE tools and functionality can enable near real-time authoring of new health data terminology concepts to maintain care quality even in the midst of unprecedented circumstances.

section.para: The use of Komet is predicated on the successful development of the wider healthcare information technology ecosystem alongside regulatory, clinical, and terminology standard stakeholders working together to support guidance and the use of such a tool. To achieve this ideal state, the SHIELD program continues to address the goal of being able to represent the same healthcare information, the same way, every time though its Integrated Knowledge Management tools. With support from stakeholders across the ecosystem, SHIELD can achieve the shared foundation necessary to improves the quality and interoperability of laboratory data.
